instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with Short to Ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and No Orange or Green Light.
threads.message:
Have a 13" MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and obviously no orange - nor green light.
I connected a charger and got no signs of heat.
So I followed the short and mis-diagnosed and removed the SMC but the short remained. Before re-installing the SMC, can I inject 3V42 on the line, say on pin 2 of L6995? (Pin 1 is not shorted to ground).
How about ISL? The old one was bad and I removed it. Should I solder a new one in place first? Would like to know for this case and future reference what I can leave off when injecting current.
Not sure if helpful, but I measured resistivity of <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground and found it to be around 33 Ohm on pretty much most parts of the line.
The board is not WD. It seems it was killed by a bad MagSafe connector or charger. It was worked on before, as it came with the B/L driver missing. The owner said it was harvested and asked me to put one back if the board powers up.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with Short to Ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and No Orange or Green Light.
threads.message: Put a good SMC and ISL on there, remove L6995, and put 3.425v from bench power supply on pin 2 of L6995, and then plug magsafe in. Anything happen?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with Short to Ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and No Orange or Green Light.
threads.message: There is a cap on audio around that spongey foamy thingie by the BIL connector that always gives <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> a slight short to ground but since this has been fucked with it could be anything at this point. :( I would just run it with a strong PSU filling in for <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, even if there is a minor short somewhere it will drive it and it should turn on unless something very important is fucked. There isn't much to <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, it powers the SMC, the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> circuitry, onewire circuitry, and some audio crap, there isn't much to fuck up there.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with Short to Ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and No Orange or Green Light.
MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with Short to Ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and No Orange or Green Light.
threads.message:
[USER="1"]larossmann[/USER] installed ISL and SMC and removed L6995, and injected 3.4V on pin 2. Got heat at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>. Removed it and removed <CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR> and found that pin 9 is still shorted to ground and resistivity of the line to ground is still 33OHM. So the short to ground is down the line.
Can I keep <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> off the board and re-inject 3V42 on pin 2 of L6995? I would think so...
EDIT: after looking at the schematics I decided to go ahead and inject 3V42 from IBM desktop power supply because my bench DCPS can dump 20 AMPS in case of short. I found <CHIP>U5755</CHIP> to be shorted (very slightly warming up). Removing it relieved the short. Gonna test and report back.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with Short to Ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and No Orange or Green Light.
threads.message: Oh and did not find any shorted cap on that line near battery level indicator connector, if that's what you mean. BIL is new to me. Unless you can give me the cap # to double check..?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with Short to Ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and No Orange or Green Light.
threads.message: I had the <CHIP>U5755</CHIP> shorted on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board the other day. Always interesting to start noticing common points of weakness. (Glad that failed than something more important)
